results.title: Barcelona [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: New Visions Pictures and Whit Stillman
results.brief_description: An off-beat and ironic talk-fest from director Whit Stillman, this is a dry, insightful comedy about two American cousins in post-Franco Spain. Ted Boynton, an overly serious salesman, who is in the midst of recovering from a broken relationship and questioning his vocation originally inspired by an Arthur Miller play, is suddenly faced with the arrival of his arrogant navy cousin Fred. What ensues is a series of intensive bar crawls where the cousins encounter a group of women from the Trade Centre, one of whom Ted promptly falls in love with. A study of the life and attitudes of two Americans abroad underlies this comic romantic tale through which the film takes on a more serious satirical tone. As the film progresses, the ineptitude of Ted and Fred to integrate with the values of the culture they inhabit is only exceeded by the anti-American sentiment in Spain which the characters do not remain untouched by, but are slow to recognise. This film will no doubt appeal to fans of Whit Stillman’s characteristic distanced play between amusement and substantial critique.

results.title: Barcelona
results.brief_description: A practical guide for travellers intending to visit the Catalonian region of Spain. Beginning in Barcelona, host John Guerrasio provides information about public transport options, accommodation, food and currency. He visits the 1992 Olympic precinct, the Joan Miro Gallery situated on Monjuic and the Ramblas. From Barcelona, he travels to Montserrat, Tarragona, the Costa Brava and Gerona highlighting the main areas of cultural and geographic interest. Also includes a visit to Antonio Gaudi’s Sagrada Familia.

results.title: Barbie in the nutcracker
results.creator_credit: Mattel, Mainframe Entertainment, Jesyca C Durchin, Jennifer Twiner McCarron and Owen Hurley
results.brief_description: Superb computer animation brings Barbie to life in this modernized adaptation of E.T.A. Hoffmann’s classic story, ‘The Nutcracker’. Story heroine Clara receives a wooden Nutcracker as a gift from an aunt. As she sleeps the Nutcracker comes to life to save her from the evil Mouse King, who has invaded Clara’s house, unfortunately. Clara wakes and is shrunk by the Mouse King. The only person who can break the Mouse King’s spell and restore Clara to her original size is the Sugarplum Fairy, so Clara and the Nutcracker set off to find her. In her first full length movie, Barbie assumes the roles of Clara and the Sugarplum Fairy. Choreographed by Peter Martins and performed for animation by the New York City Ballet. Tchaikovsky’s musical score is performed by the London Symphony Orchestra. Features voices from Kelly Sheridan (Barbie/Clara), Kirby Morrow (Nutcracker/Prince Eric),Tim Curry (Mouse King), Peter Kelamis (Pimm), Christopher Gaze (Major Mint), Ian James Corlett (Captain Candy), French Tickner (Grandfather Drosselmayer) and Kathleen Barr (Aunt Drosselmayer).

results.title: Barbed wire and mandolins
results.creator_credit: Sam Grana, Nicola Zaraglia and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: When Italy became an active player in the Second World War in 1940, the Canadian government began to fear the Italian community within Canada as a threat to national security. The action they took was to use the Canadian Mounted Police Force to contain alleged facist sympathizers. Seven hundred of the accused sympathizers were held in internment camps for up to three years. The majority of detainees were held at Petawawa, Ontario. Through interviewing Italian-Canadians who were affected by these actions, one discovers that there was a spirit of camaraderie and hope amongst those at Petawawa as the internees coped with their situation in the any way they could, such as through music, art and gardening. Despite these diversions, what they have lost financially and socially in the community remains with them forever.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sam Grana, Nicola Zaraglia and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Barbarian diplomacy
results.creator_credit: Peter Minns, BBC and Oxford Film and Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Chris Patten’s east and west”.
First of the three part documentary series “Chris Patten’s East and West” written and presented by the former British governor of Hong Kong, Chris Patten. In this episode Patten focuses on China - socially, economically and politically - from its past history to the China of the 90s. He more specifically deals with human rights and economic reform emphasising his strong belief that it is important “to keep trade and human rights separate” and that “economical reform requires political reform”. The program covers President Nixon’s visit and his meeting with Mao Tse-tung in 1972; the US/China alliance and lifting of trade restrictions; the rise of Deng Xaioping and the reform movement following Mao’s death; the Tiananmen Square massacre of 1989; international and trade relations at the expense of human rights recognition; President Clinton’s visit in 1998. Also briefly looks at human rights issues in Burma through an interview with the Burmese Opposition Leader, Aung San Suu Kyi who has been politically isolated under house arrest for over 9 years, followed by a comparison to Taiwan, a mainly Chinese capitalist society, democratic and free and a thorn in China’s side. Includes interviews with Henry Kissinger (US National Security Adviser 1969-75), Paul Wolfowitz (US Assistant Secretary of State, Asia 1982-86), Winston Lord (US Foreign Policy Adviser 1970-73) and Sir Alan Donald (British Ambassador, Beijing 1988-91) among others. Contains b&w archival footage and stills.

results.title: Barbarella [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Dino De Laurentiis, Marianne Productions, De Laurentiis Entertainment Group and Roger Vadim
results.brief_description: This cult film by New Wave director Roger Vadim begins with a flawlessly executed zero gravity strip-tease by the film’s feisty 41st century space adventurer, Barbarella (Jane Fonda). The adventure begins when the president of Earth contacts Barbarella for her help in locating Durand Durand (Milo O’Shea), a young scientist who has vanished with a deadly positronic ray that contains the power to “shatter the loving union of the universe”. Her mission takes an unexpected twist after her fur-lined vessel makes a forced landing on the icy planet Lythion after being rocked by a magnetic disturbance. Barbarella soon faces a number of challenging situations that result in many costume changes, and pleasurable encounters with the handsome men who assist her as she continues to track the elusive Durand Durand. With the help of the angel, Pygar (John Phillip Law), Barbarella must infiltrate the city of SoGo and battle the Black Guards and the Great Tyrant - a sadistic seductress who wants Barbarella for her own devious purposes - to recover the devastating weapon and restore peace and order to the galaxy. Based on the French science-fiction comic by Jean-Claude Forest, with dazzling and inventive costume design by Jacques Fonteray and Paco Rabanne.

constellations_other.name: Retrofuturism: aesthetic impact of space design on screen culture
constellations_other.description: Humans have long imagined the future, including prospective travel to space and what living life away from planet earth could look like. This extending to designing interiors of domestic spaces and how these have then influenced the aesthetics of screen culture through set building and design.

results.title: Baraka [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Mark Magidson, Magidson Films and Ron Fricke
results.brief_description: Shot in 24 countries, “Baraka” is an extraordinary visual feast that examines the passionate and destructive love/hate relationship between humans and earth. A spectacular diversity of memorable images have been gathered from around the world from the natural and man-made environments, both past and present. The style is strongly reminiscent of the film “Koyaanisqatsi” in its use of timelapse photography juxtaposed with slower sequences, and the somewhat sentimental, simplistic portrayal of humanity.

results.title: Bapteme
results.creator_credit: Louis Wipf, Eric Trotta and Rene Feret
results.brief_description:
In 1935, near Bethune (northern France), Aline marries Pierre instead of the man who had been chosen for her. After their honeymoon, Aline replaces her mother running a small cafe while Pierre works on fairs and markets. Largely inspired by the real story of his parents, Rene Feret’s film chronicles the ups and downs of a working class couple from the 1930’s to the 1960’s.

Credits: Producers, Eric Trotta, Louis Wipf ; director, Rene Feret ; writer, Rene Feret ; photography, Pierre Lhomme ; music, Frederic Chopin, Evelyne Stroh.
Cast: Valerie Stroh, Jean-Yves Berteloot, Jacques Bonnaffe, Pierre-Alain Chapuis, Edith Scob, Elsa Zylberstein.

results.title: Bantu tribes of Southern Africa
results.creator_credit: Willem Vilioen and Paul Hoefler Special Productions
results.brief_description: Describes the old ways of life among the Zulu, Xhosa, Swazi, Ndebele, Sotho and Venda tribes. These various Bantu groups are now being brought into the South African industrial community. Outlines the ways in which this movement is changing the culture of the tribes and the struggle to preserve some of the old ways.
